label.text: UV Light Damage
Ozone (O₃) is a gas found in the atmosphere. It forms a layer in the stratosphere, which covers the entire Earth at about 10 km to 50 km above Earth’s surface.
In the past, the ozone layer was partially destroyed by the release of ozone-depleting gases.
The reduction of ozone in the atmosphere caused an increase in irreversible eye and skin damage.
Many countries now ban the use of ozone-depleting gases. As a result, the ozone layer is slowly recovering.
How does the presence of ozone in the atmosphere provide protection against irreversible eye and skin damage?
Ozone helps human skin reflect sunlight.
Ozone reflects radiation from the Sun back into space.
Ozone converts damaging chemicals from the atmosphere into safe ones.
Ozone reduces the level of ultraviolet (UV) radiation reaching Earth’s surface.
The eye and skin damage because of ozone depletion in two towns was compared. Both towns had the same concentration of ozone in the atmosphere.
Which of the following facts about the towns could account for any variation in the results between the towns?
Select all correct answers.
One town has greater access to healthcare.
The population size of each town is the same.
Suncare products are more expensive in one town.
Both towns provide education about suncare.
More outdoor work is done in one town.
Methyl bromide is an ozone-depleting gas. In some countries, methyl bromide is used to protect imported and exported goods from insects and disease.
Which one of the following statements provides a reasonable justification for the continued use of methyl bromide?
Methyl bromide can be used until viable alternatives are developed to avoid disrupting the world economy.
Methyl bromide can be used because finding alternatives will be too expensive and time consuming.
Methyl bromide can be used because the ozone layer is recovering and therefore ozone depleting chemicals are no longer a problem.
Methyl bromide can be used because humans will eventually evolve immunity and will no longer be affected by UV radiation.
